{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3325573,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-06T14:16:31.733Z","cooked":"

How does your team primarily write commands?

  • Inline definitions/factory functions (e.g. run, runOnce)
  • Explicit subclasses of Command
0 voters

Last year, I ran a poll asking teams which usage pattern they preferred for interacting with the WPILib command-based framework. The results suggested a fairly even split between functional/factory-based usage and ‚Äútraditional‚Äù subclassing.

A year later, the library has continued to develop and the ‚Äúfunctional‚Äù usage pattern now has a number of new convenience features and substantially improved documentation - as well as being featured in the KitBot code. So, I‚Äôm running the poll again.

As before, feel free to elaborate below on specifics of your team‚Äôs usage of the library. Please note that the question asks about primary usage - it is understood that teams generally do not exclusively write commands one way or the other.

Racovan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a3d4f5/{size}.png","title":""}]},"chart_type":"bar","title":null}]},{"id":3325588,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-06T14:38:03.719Z","cooked":"

The students have come around to preferring inline command definitions and BooleanSupplier methods.

And all that without any formal classroom training. We ran out of time and didn‚Äôt finish the basic Java training and never got to Command-Based.

Students are picking it up by doing and a little too much looking at mentors for what command to use to accomplish what they want and we then look at a cheat sheet I made.

Next season we need to save space in the schedule for a couple of hours of training time for Command-Based.

I wish I could vote for both options.

For Python, code maintenance is so much less contrained than Java that explicity subclasses can be quite nice. They end up requiring just about the same number of lines of code (depending on your linter).

I‚Äôm also a huge fan of our current setup where we have a single file that define any commands that touch more than one subsystem.

Commands that only use a single subsystem live in the subystem source file directly, or are composed inline.

We have seen some inline command compositions that haven‚Äôt worked as expected (meaning, not being scheduled or working) that we haven‚Äôt tracked down root cause‚Ä¶but I think it‚Äôs likely a skill issue.

Edit to add:
Our total robot code this year is 9 source files. The simplicity is great.

We have 8 (!!!) software students this year and already get enough merge conflicts as it is so we try to do as much as possible in separate files. I would say we lean maybe too hard into ‚Äúseparation of concerns‚Äù. It isn‚Äôt the most elegant or ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù but it seems to be working for us so far. We still do use inline instant commands for some things though.

NewtonCrosby:

For Python, code maintenance is so much less contrained than Java that explicity subclasses can be quite nice. They end up requiring just about the same number of lines of code (depending on your linter).

Mind sharing a side-by-side comparison for those unfamiliar with the Python API?

I‚Äôm not much of a command-based programmer, but the answers don‚Äôt line up with my understanding of the question. To me, to ‚Äúwrite commands‚Äù refers more to the fundamental code of each ‚Äúelemental‚Äù command, independent of how they are started, stopped, or linked into composite commands. The answers address instantiation, linkage to events, and making composite commands. Is my understanding that out of date, or can the question be asked more clearly?

Nonetheless, I am pleased to see greater adoption of the inline and factory methods. They are much easier to read [even though I am not at all ready to write them), and I suspect much much easier to troubleshoot, adjust, and update.

Would you mind posting said cheat sheet?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T00:41:57.057Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":46.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457539,"topic_slug":"2024-command-based-usage-patterns","display_username":"Manish Reddy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24594,"username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63043,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3019 Programmer and Operator"},"post_url":"/t/2024-command-based-usage-patterns/457539/7","custom_user_title":"3019 Programmer and Operator","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326368,"name":"NewtonCrosby","username":"NewtonCrosby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ed8c4c/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T00:56:11.134Z","cooked":"

It‚Äôs not the Python API per se, just that Python makes it really easy to stash multiple things in the same source file, making organization quite simple.

# Right below the Subsystem definition
class DefaultDriveCommand(Command):
    def __init__(self, dt: Drivetrain, controller: CommandXboxController):
        super().__init__()
        self._dt = dt
        self._controller = controller
        self.addRequirements(self._dt)

    def execute(self):
         forward = -self._controller.getLeftY() 
         turn = -self._controller.getRightX() if Robotbase.isReal() else -self._driver_controller.getRawAxis(
                constants.CONTROLLER_TURN_SIM)

Whereas:

if wpilib.RobotBase.isSimulation():
            # Set the Drivetrain to arcade drive by default
            self._drivetrain.setDefaultCommand(
                # A split-stick arcade command, with forward/backward controlled by the left
                # hand, and turning controlled by the right.
                RunCommand(
                    lambda: self._drivetrain.drive_teleop(
                        -self._driver_controller.getRawAxis(
                            constants.CONTROLLER_FORWARD_SIM
                        ),
                        -self._driver_controller.getRawAxis(
                            constants.CONTROLLER_TURN_SIM
                        ),
                    ),
                    self._drivetrain,
                ).withName("DefaultDrive")
            )
        else:
            self._drivetrain.setDefaultCommand(
                # A split-stick arcade command, with forward/backward controlled by the left
                # hand, and turning controlled by the right.
                RunCommand(
                    lambda: self._drivetrain.drive_teleop(
                        -self._driver_controller.getLeftY(),
                        -self._driver_controller.getRightX(),
                    ),
                    self._drivetrain,
                ).withName("DefaultDrive")
            )

I‚Äôm sure there are ways to get the inline composition more compact than it is, I jsut like the fact that I can just toss that guy in the bottom of the same drivetrain.py file, and it‚Äôs there. Essentially I like having options I guess.

Mostly factory, but the really important commands are explicit subclasses because we need to control when and how they end.

So if we could only do one it would be the explicit subclasses. However, I prefer to use the factory version wherever possible.

This year, each subsystem has an applyRequest method like CTRE SwerveDrivetrain.java class. They have a SwerveRequest interface with several implementations, each with a different apply, all representing different ways of controlling the subsystem.

We liked the approach and so inter-subsystem like auton can be handled with inline, but for the most part, we can define our different control types as objects, not methods or separate commands when they are pretty similar to each other. Check out our code at HOC-Team-3534/MusicalToaster (github.com).
